text:
Good afternoon you wonderful people! I'm Bill and very new to this freelance-gig life. I havea question that maybe some of you have run into: I recently started sending my client invoices. I'm in Germany and the client is in Italy. I also do some freelance teaching (ESL) at the local university. When I invoice the school, I have a fiscal ID number that was assigned to me so I can get paid and I can't use this number for other purposes. I also pay German taxes, jointly, and I have a number for that. My Italian client asked me to provide a Fiscal ID on the invoices I send. I'm not a German Gewerbe, but I am considered a Kleinunternehmer in the freelance/freiberufler domain. I'm also an American.  If I use my passport number as a fiscal id, that may cause me problems down the road. Can anyone give me some advice on what I can do to get a fiscal ID number for my client in Italy? Do they assign a number to me? If so, why is the bookkeeping department asking for a fiscal id number? (I don't provide enough services to collect VAT for the German Finance Ministry, so I don't have that number I can use.)

Thanks for the leg up. Wishing everyone a miraculous day!

text: Has anyone heard of Bonsai? Any reviews? Just learned about it yesterday and I'm intrigued by all of the tools, but I'm wondering if its ACH payments option is as easy-to-use as Quickbooks Self-Employed, since I'm looking to avoid ever accepting payments via CC. <https://www.hellobonsai.com/>

attachments.title: The #1 Freelance Product Suite - Bonsai
attachments.text: Bulletproof contracts, e-signing, proposals & invoicing software used by 200,000+ top freelancers. Get peace of mind & focus on your work.

elements.text: Has anyone heard of Bonsai? Any reviews? Just learned about it yesterday and I'm intrigued by all of the tools, but I'm wondering if its ACH payments option is as easy-to-use as Quickbooks Self-Employed, since I'm looking to avoid ever accepting payments via CC.

text: I'm also interested in this if anyone has insights.
